text: Cellular Communication Introduction to Signalling Molecular Medicine 2021 Dr N Whalley, Natalie.Whalley@wits.ac.za Objectives •Describe different types of intercellular signalling •Name the different components of hydrophobic and hydrophilic signalling pathways and describe their role in signalling. •Compare hydrophobic with hydrophilic signalling •Be able to describe or draw the RTK pathway Part 1: Intercellular communication Intercellular Communication Autocrine: Signalling molecule secreted by cell and bind to cell surface receptors on same cell that produced them. AUTOCRINE Intercellular Communication Paracrine: Signalling molecules are released into the extracellular space and act locally on neighboring cells. Signalling molecules rapidly degraded Molecular Biology of Cell, 4th Ed, Alberts Contact-dependent signalling/ Cell to cell signalling: Cells need to be in direct membrane-membrane contact. Synaptic signalling: Performed by neurons that transmit signals electrically along their axons and release neurotransmitters at synapses, which are often located far away from the cell body. Intercellular CommunicationIntercellular Communication Endocrine: Depends on endocrine cells, which secrete hormones into the bloodstream that are then distributed widely throughout the body. Adaptors •Relatively small proteins with usually no more than two or three domains whose function is to link two proteins together •Proteins with SH2 domains bind to phosphorylated tyrosine amino acids. Protein Phosphorylation + + Protein Phosphorylation • More than one site on a polypeptide chain can be phosphorylated • Phosphorylation adds two negative charges (phosphate group) to protein –conformational change •Activity •Interactions •Location • Target proteins can be phosphorylated by more than one kinase –Thus kinases activated by different signalling pathways can result in phosphorylation of the same protein • NB in signalling pathways and regulation of cell cycle 6. Scaffold Proteins •Large proteins able to bind various other proteins to bring them together in a complex •Have no enzymatic activity •They can be phosphorylated at various sites and thus recruit many different proteins with SH2 domains. 7. Transcription Factors •Proteins that bind to promoters of genes and either increase or decrease transcription of gene •Promoter contains conserved consensus sequence which binds general transcription factors and other specific sequences which bind specific transcription factors eg NFκB, AP-1. •Specific Transcription factors gives specificity to signal. •Genes with promoters with same sequences will bind same TFs giving a combined response. Part 4: Receptor Tyrosine Kinase signalling Receptor Tyrosine Kinase (RTK) signalling Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Signalling •Currently more than 60 known receptor tyrosine kinases which are involved in cellular signalling pathways •Regulate key cellular processes such as proliferation, differentiation, development, angiogenesis and survival. •Unregulated activation of this pathway, can lead to cancer as well as to benign proliferative conditions. Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Signalling •Also play a role in inflammatory diseases and diabetes. •Targeted molecular therapies against members of the RTK receptor family were among the first to be used –Trastuzumab: Herceptin (anti-HER2) –Gefitinib (anti-EGFR), –many others are presently used and being developed. Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Signalling: Ligands • This pathway regulates cellular responses to growth factors. • Epidermal growth factor (EGF) is produced by macrophages, platelets and epithelial cells in various organs, including kidney, salivary gland and stomach. It contains a hydrophobic domain allowing it to be anchored in the plasma membrane • Platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) has crucial roles during development It is produced by platelets, smooth muscle cells, activated macrophages, and endothelial cells amongst others. Some are secreted in an inactive form and are cleaved by proteases in ECM and activated • Fibroblast growth factor (FGF) is particularly important in the control of development. The heparan sulphate proteoglycans play an important role in cell signalling by binding growth factors such as FGF and PDGF, which thus serves to restrict their action to areas close to their sites of release Receptor Tyrosine Kinase Signalling: Ligands • Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) plays a major role in angiogenesis • Angiopoeitins: The primary function of the angiopoietins is to control angiogenesis. Also NB in cell adhesion of haematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) to the stem cell niche All of these growth factors play important roles in wound healing. y y y y y y y y y y y y Ligand: GF, EGF, PDGF
